(i.e., xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" on the root element)

Yes

Heard about the EDPS suggestion for webbrowser builders?
No, what is it?
EDPS is the European privacy watchdog
they want that browser vendors by default refuse cookies from advertising networks
http://www.edps.europa.eu/EDPSWEB/webdav/site/mySite/shared/Documents/Consultation/Opinions/2010/10-03-19_Trust_Information_Society_EN.pdf
See page 17 onward
"Validation can then be used as a quick check to determine whether the code is the clean work of a seasoned HTML author, or quickly hacked-together tag soup."
The steps that users must take to opt-out seem not only complicated but also excessive (first he must set his browser to accept cookies, then exercise the opt-out option).

Therefore, while legally speaking, Article 5(3) of the ePrivacy Directive provides for effective legal protection, in practice, Internet users are deemed to consent to be monitored for the purposes of sending behavioural advertisement when in fact, in many, if not most cases, they are fully unaware that the monitoring takes place.

As described above, web browsers commonly allow a level of control over certain kinds of cookies. Currently, the default settings of most web browsers are accepting all cookies. In other words, by default, the browsers are set to accept all cookies, independently of the purpose of the cookie.
[...] Furthermore, there is no privacy wizard on the first install or update of browser applications.
Looks like they're urging on legislation as well.
Which would mean that browsers in the EU would have to refuse 3rd party cookies by default
and implement a privacy wizard
I wonder if they know about SharedObjects
"Currently, the default settings of most web browsers are accepting all cookies."
Is this actually true? I thought most browsers only allowed first-party and redirect cookies by default?
My Opera says "Accept cookies" (not "only from the site I visit"), and I don't think I've ever changed it away from the default
My firefox 3.6.2 under privacy has no specific cookie setting option, not unless you select use custom settings for history
and that shows accept third-party
The default was changed to "Accept cookies only from the site I visit" in 10.50 and reverted in 10.51
The only vanilla browser I have to check is Safari, and it says "only sites I visit"
"There is a need for more granularity and clear information on the types of cookies and the usefulness of some of them."
Fair point.
The user eduction tools will save us
the LART?
I don't think many people would answer "Why yes, I do want my browsing habits to be tracked and recorded for other people's profit"
And I seem to recall from bug reports that some sites break without 3rd party cookies, so that's an incentive to enable it anyhow
wow, presence of xmlns as talisman of best-practices opt-in
<html xmlns="I support best practices">
we time-travels 10 years into the future and gets killed by people there who end up getting stuck with the long-term consequences of that one
Aren't those sites maybe broken by design then? :)

If Opera changed back in 10.51, was that because of bug reports of sites breaking, or was it the result of a successful attempt to extort protection money for ad networks by showing them Opera's power to turn cookies off in 10.50?

gsnedders: Oh
asmodai, "Eloi" isn't Hebrew for "father", or Aramaic.  Maybe it's Greek?
Greek likes ending words in "oi".
Although usually as a masculine plural, I thought.
"Father, Father, why have you forsaken me?" would probably be something like "Avi, avi, lama azavtani?" in Biblical Hebrew.
Maybe Jesus was screaming profanities, but the English translators thought it would be better to pretend he said "Father" instead
heh

There are no profanities in Biblical Hebrew, it's all very euphemistic.  There aren't even words for things like "urine", as far as I know.  Presumably such words existed, but nobody saw fit to write them down in holy texts.
AryehGregor: And the New Testement was mainly written in Greek, no?
Well, I'm hardly an expert on the New Testament, but that's my impression, yes.
Wikipedia agrees

"Eli" means "my God", not "my Father".  Don't recognize "sabachtani", not sure if it's cognate to a Hebrew word I recognize.
"My God, My God, why have you forsaken me?"

"Survey results on question "should W3C publish HTML 5 under a license that allows forking?". Of those who responded, approximately 79% answered "no" and 14% answered "yes" (and the rest abstained)."

I wonder why they want to attempt to prohibit forking, when the W3C version is already a fork itself

It's only bad when people other than you do it.
Fork is a loaded word, after all
It implies there still being an original
Does it?

<3 Unicode

When there's a fork in a road, I'd expect that to be two equally divergent paths
"Fork" implies there's still an original, at the moment of forking.
One or the other may subsequently die, of course.
and in a utensil-style fork I wouldn't expect there to be a primary tine

so it's odd that in software it has a different connotation

bifurcation doesn't imply a original either, does it?
It implies one thing becoming two.
Not with either one necessarily different from the other.

"Conclusion: For HTML 5, create a new license that addresses all of the use cases cited by the HTML Working Group except forking." - maybe the best way to address the uses cases would be to not address them, to avoid wasting effort given the WHATWG copy already addresses the use cases in a far simpler and less proliferatively way

each piece in <article>

s? I feel like the entire group is either an article or a section.

yes, each <article> has an obvious heading. I'm talking about the parent element.
the parent element doesn't have its own heading, so far as I can see
Yes, I'm refering to the parent element which wraps all of the articles.  At Liferay.com, we do have a heading to label the banners.

banners

Whereas an archive may be such, previews of blog posts or a rotating banner may not.
They are pieces of independantly distributable or reusable content.
